title: no_title
body: My dad had to have a total laryngectomy about 2 years ago due to laryngeal cancer. Living in the rural south, he and my mom have to drive about 3.5 hours (one way) when it is time for that prosthetic voice apparatus to  be changed out. 7 total hours of driving and heavy, traffic in a tourist city around a busy research hospital is tough. I did that drive many times for them when he was still undergoing treatments and having surgeries. He has found that the closer he gets to needing the prosthetic changed, the more he coughs when he drinks water or other thin liquids. He describes it as "leaking". Also, there are time when he feels that the prosthetic shifts and presses against the back of the throat causing choking. But since the visits to have the prosthetic reinstalled or adjusted are costly and not a hop, skip and jump away, he endures the discomfort. It feels to him like the prosthetic has shifted and is allowing liquid to leak into his lungs -- and as a result, convulsive coughing ensues. So I ordered this and it helps. He is still about a week and a half away from his next appointment to be refitted and the coughing is still really bad but with the thickener, its bearable. Before, he was so miserable and bitter that he was lashing out and being exceptionally negative. (He may have also been getting dehydrated which can cause mood disturbances.) He was absolutely killing my mom. That constant crossness and lashing out can really do a number on the spouse who has had to assume the role of "caretaker". I mean, my Dad is not disabled, but the ordeal of cancer has changed him and he depends on her more and sometimes seems to resent her "wholeness".Since he got this product (only 5 days ago), he and my mom (who are both retired) have taken two nice day trips to shop and eat in cities about an hour away all in the same week. All before, he had been sitting in the house day after day saying one negative thing after the other, vegging out in front of the tv and feeding off of negative news programs. Now he's out on a "date" with my mom and he is even talking about getting a nice room and spending the night with my mom in Charleston when they drive down for his refitting. body: My dog has a condition called laryngeal paralysis. This is where the flaps to the windpipe don't work anymore and she could not breath. This made it hard for her to drink with out having some of the water go down the wrong pipe and she coughed and choked after every drinking. Eating was fine, just the drinking. I saw this product and im glad I did! You add a little powder to the liquid, stir it good, then let it sit for 30 seconds and it slowly thickens. You have to play around with the amount until you get the right thickness. For 4 fluid oz I use 2 table spoons but I am still playing with the amount. This has helped my dog very much. She can drink now with out it going down the wrong pipe. I tasted it just to see what I was dealing with and you don't taste a difference. Just the texture is different.  I, like another person posted would love to find an organic version, but this is truly a godsend for us.

body: I have used Thick it for several years now. Husband has upper dysphagia (a swallow disorder) Upper Dysphagia has no cure, but you can help by using this. It will help lessen events of Aspiration Pneumonia. Dysphagia can be caused by things such as stroke, Cancer of the throat and even repeat pneumonia episodes mainly in the elderly. This product can also be used with infants and small children,  however,  NEVER give a baby or small child any new changes to his diet without a Dr's order.Thick it is tasteless. Remember that it takes an adjustment period to any patient going to a  regular liquid to a thicker consistency, so keep practicing in how much you use. A little hint: Start out a bit thicker than needed. The patient will say they aren't drinking that! Then make another small amount with a little less thickness. Make sure a cold drink is really COLD! I add ice to the drink BEFORE the thick it,  stir the ice till it's mostly melted,  then scoop out the remaining ice cube ( you DON'T want them to choke!) NOW add thick it! What a person with swallowing issues desires is a refreshing cold going down the throat. I really give it a fast hard stir till powder is well dissolved. You may add a touch of lemon to water,  a little real (or artificial if diabetic) sugar to make it a little more flavorful. My husband loves ice tea. I use the above method of making it. He has to have very close to pudding thick and uses a spoon to "eat" it. Swallow issues state using NO straws or sports bottles. Be sure the patient can be positioned @ 30 degree angle ( NO LAYING FLAT!!) The patient can aspirate anything if they are laying down. Just practice using patient's face drinks till you get good results in thickness needed.  Thicken applesauce, soup broth, ect. I think the 2 most difficult things to thicken are milk and coffee. A person with dysphagia will have a limited diet change. Cold cereal, things like Cole slaw,  salad ( basic foods that can choke must be avoided! Have your Dr order speech therapy. Medicare will pay for 100% for IN HOME care. Use that insurance FIRST ! Many visits to the home are allowed before they stop paying! Easier on the patient to learn swallow excercises in comfort of home.  Home health is there to also help show you tips, train you and make you confident in what you're doing. By time home health care is done,  patient will understand why the excercises, ect are so important & you (Caregiver) will be able to handle this health issue like a pro. Patience & common sense are the key!

body: I was forced to consume this stuff in the hospital after a tracheotomy, and I thought I'd never want to see it again! However, I eventually realized something like this could come in very handy in the kitchen. My previous go-to no-cook thickener was xanthan gum, but my son HATES when I use it in anything! This *just* thickens things, without making them stretchy or slimy or lumpy. When I pack lunches, I add it to tuna & chicken salad to thicken up the lemon juice or vinegar and help keep the bread from getting soggy; I've used it to thicken up runny store-bought jam, yogurt, and cottage cheese. I use it to replace some of the mayo in creamy salad dressings and sugar in cake frosting, thereby reducing the calories. It helps stabilize whipped cream.It is the same starch used in instant pudding mixes, so you can use it to create your own recipes (with fewer artificial flavors/colors, if desired), or turn any beverage like juice, soda, iced coffee, or flavored milk (chocolate, strawberry, Ovaltine, etc) into a pudding. Mixes & dissolves so well in hot or cold liquid! I find it more convenient than regular cornstarch, which has to be dissolved in cold liquid;  if you've already added all the ingredients to your recipe but it's looking watery, you can just stir in some Thick-It without adding more liquid as you'd have to with cornstarch. In my opinion, some thickeners like cornstarch or glucomannan dull the flavor of my food, while Thick-It either doesn't have that effect or it must be much more subtle, because I don't notice a change in flavor. I love this stuff! It is pure carbs so, being diabetic, I do have to use it sparingly, but a teaspoon or a tablespoon is usually quite enough for a recipe that makes several servings.
